Text

Once there were [four children]208-four children whose names were [Peter]69-peter , [Susan]70-susan , [Edmund]71-edmund and [Lucy]72-lucy , and it has been told in another book called [The Lion]73-the lion , [the Witch and the Wardrobe]209-the witch and the wardrobe how [they]208-four children had a remarkable adventure . [They]208-four children had opened the door of a magic wardrobe and found [themselves]208-four children in [a quite different world from [ours]211-ours]210-a quite different world from ours , and in [that different world]212-that different world [they]208-four children had become [Kings]213-kings and [Queens]214-queens in [a country called [Narnia]1-narnia]215-a country called narnia . While [they]208-four children were in [Narnia]1-narnia [they]208-four children seemed to reign for years and years ; but when [they]208-four children came back through the door and found [themselves]208-four children in [England]2-england again , it all seemed to have taken no time at all . At any rate , [no one]216-no one noticed that [they]208-four children had ever been away , and [they]208-four children never told [anyone]217-anyone except [one very wise grown - up]218-one very wise grown - up .

That had all happened a year ago , and now [all four of [them]219-all four of them]219-all four of them were sitting on a seat at [a railway station]220-a railway station with trunks and playboxes piled up round [them]208-four children . [They]208-four children were , in fact , on [their]208-four children way back to [school]221-school . [They]208-four children had travelled together as far as [this station]222-this station , which was [a junction]223-a junction ; and here , in a few minutes , [one train]224-one train would arrive and take [the girls]225-the girls away to [one school]226-one school , and in about half an hour [another train]227-another train would arrive and [the boys]228-the boys would go off to [another school]229-another school . The first part of the journey , when [they]208-four children were all together , always seemed to be part of the holidays ; but now when [they]208-four children would be saying good - by and going different ways so soon , [everyone]230-everyone felt that the holidays were really over and [everyone]230-everyone felt [their]230-everyone term time feelings beginning again , and [they]208-four children were all rather gloomy and [no - one]232-no - one could think of anything to say . [Lucy]72-lucy was going to [boarding school]233-boarding school for the first time .

It was [an empty , sleepy , country station]234-an empty , sleepy , country station and there was hardly anyone on [the platform]235-the platform except [themselves]208-four children . Suddenly [Lucy]72-lucy gave a sharp little cry , like [someone who has been stung by a wasp]236-someone who has been stung by a wasp .

" What 's up , [Lu]72-lucy ? "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund â€” and then suddenly broke off and made a noise like " Ow ! "[71-edmund]

" What on earth â€” â€” "[69-peter] began [Peter]69-peter , and then [he]69-peter too suddenly changed what [he]69-peter had been going to say . Instead , [he]69-peter said , " [Susan]70-susan , let go ! What are [you]70-susan doing ? Where are [you]70-susan dragging [me]69-peter to ? "[69-peter]

" [I]70-susan 'm not touching [you]69-peter , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan . " [Someone]1462-someone is pulling [me]70-susan . Oh â€” oh â€” oh â€” stop it ! "[70-susan]

[Everyone]230-everyone noticed that [all the others]238-all the others ' faces had gone very white .

" [I]71-edmund felt just the same , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund in a breathless voice . " As if [I]71-edmund were being dragged along . A most frightful pulling â€” ugh ! it 's beginning again . "[71-edmund]

" [Me]72-lucy too , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . " Oh , [I]72-lucy ca n't bear it . "[72-lucy]

" Look sharp ! "[71-edmund] shouted [Edmund]71-edmund . " [All]1463-all catch hands and keep together . This is magic â€” [I]71-edmund can tell by the feeling . Quick ! "[71-edmund]

" Yes , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan . " Hold hands . Oh , [I]70-susan do wish it would stop â€” oh ! "[70-susan]

Next moment the luggage , the seat , [the platform]235-the platform , and [the station]240-the station had completely vanished . [The four children , holding hands and panting]241-the four children , holding hands and panting , found [themselves]241-the four children , holding hands and panting standing in a woody place â€” such a woody place that branches were sticking into [them]241-the four children , holding hands and panting and there was hardly room to move . [They]241-the four children , holding hands and panting all rubbed [their]241-the four children , holding hands and panting eyes and took a deep breath .

" Oh , [Peter]69-peter ! "[72-lucy] exclaimed [Lucy]72-lucy . " Do [you]69-peter think [we]241-the four children , holding hands and panting can possibly have got back to [Narnia]1-narnia ? "[72-lucy]

" It might be anywhere , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter , " [I]69-peter ca n't see [a yard]1464-a yard in all these trees . Let 's try to get into the open â€” if there is any open . "[69-peter]

With some difficulty , and with some stings from nettles and pricks from thorns , [they]241-the four children , holding hands and panting struggled out of the thicket . Then [they]241-the four children , holding hands and panting had another surprise . Everything became much brighter , and after a few steps [they]241-the four children , holding hands and panting found [themselves]241-the four children , holding hands and panting at the edge of the wood , looking down on [a sandy beach]242-a sandy beach . A few yards away [a very calm sea]243-a very calm sea was falling on the sand with such tiny ripples that it made hardly any sound . There was no land in sight and no clouds in the sky . The sun was about where it ought to be at ten o'clock in the morning , and [the sea]244-the sea was a dazzling blue . [They]241-the four children , holding hands and panting stood sniffing in [the sea - smell]245-the sea - smell .

" By Jove ! "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " This is good enough . "[69-peter]

Five minutes later [everyone]230-everyone was barefooted and wading in the cool clear water .

" This is better than being in [a stuffy train]1465-a stuffy train on the way back to [Latin]3-latin and French and [Algebra]74-algebra ! "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund . And then for quite a long time there was no more talking , only splashing and looking for shrimps and crabs .

" All the same , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan presently , " [I]70-susan suppose [we]241-the four children , holding hands and panting 'll have to make some plans . [We]241-the four children , holding hands and panting shall want something to eat before long . "[70-susan]

" [We]241-the four children , holding hands and panting 've got the sandwiches [Mother]75-mother gave [us]241-the four children , holding hands and panting for the journey , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund . " At least [I]71-edmund 've got [mine]71-edmund . "[71-edmund]

" Not [me]72-lucy , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . " [Mine]72-lucy were in [my]72-lucy little bag . "[72-lucy]

" So were mine , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan .

" [Mine]69-peter are in [my]69-peter coat - pocket , there on [the beach]1466-the beach , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " That 'll be two lunches among four . This is n't going to be such fun . "[69-peter]

" At present , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy , " [I]72-lucy want something to drink more than something to eat . "[72-lucy]

[Everyone else]247-everyone else now felt thirsty , as one usually is after wading in salt water under a hot sun .

" It 's like being shipwrecked , "[71-edmund] remarked [Edmund]71-edmund . " In the books [they]1467-they always find springs of clear , fresh water on [the island]1468-the island . [We]1469-we 'd better go and look for them . "[71-edmund]

" Does that mean [we]1469-we have to go back into [all that thick wood]1470-all that thick wood ? "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan .

" Not a bit of it , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " If there are [streams]1471-streams [they]1471-streams 're bound to come down to [the sea]244-the sea , and if [we]1469-we walk along [the beach]1466-the beach [we]1469-we 're bound to come to [them]1471-streams . "[69-peter]

[They]248-they all now waded back and went first across the smooth , wet sand and then up to the dry , crumbly sand that sticks to one 's toes , and began putting on [their]248-they shoes and socks . [Edmund]71-edmund and [Lucy]72-lucy wanted to leave [them]248-they behind and do [their]248-they exploring with bare feet , but [Susan]70-susan said this would be a mad thing to do . " [We]1469-we might never find [them]248-they again , "[70-susan] [she]70-susan pointed out , " and [we]1469-we shall want [them]248-they if [we]1469-we 're still [here]1474-here when night comes and it begins to be cold . "[70-susan]

When [they]248-they were dressed again [they]248-they set out along [the shore]249-the shore with [the sea]244-the sea on [their]248-they left hand and the wood on [their]248-they right . Except for an occasional seagull it was [a very quiet place]251-a very quiet place . [The wood]252-the wood was so thick and tangled that [they]248-they could hardly see into it at all ; and nothing in [it]252-the wood moved â€” not a bird , not even an insect .

Shells and seaweed and anemones , or tiny crabs in rock - pools , are all very well , but [you]253-you soon get tired of them if [you]253-you are thirsty . [The children]254-the children 's feet , after the change from the cool water , felt hot and heavy . [Susan]70-susan and [Lucy]72-lucy had raincoats to carry . [Edmund]71-edmund had put down [his]71-edmund coat on the station seat just before the magic overtook [them]248-they , and [he]71-edmund and [Peter]69-peter took it in turns to carry [Peter]69-peter 's great - coat .

Presently [the shore]249-the shore began to curve round to the right . About quarter of an hour later , after [they]248-they had crossed [a rocky ridge]256-a rocky ridge which ran out into a point , [it]256-a rocky ridge made quite a sharp turn . [Their]248-they backs were now to the part of [the sea]244-the sea which had met [them]248-they when [they]248-they first came out of [the wood]252-the wood , and now , looking ahead , [they]248-they could see across the water another shore , thickly wooded like [the one [they]248-they were exploring]259-the one they were exploring .

" [I]72-lucy wonder , is that [an island]1475-an island or do [we]248-they join on to [it]1475-an island presently ? "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy .

" Do n't know , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter and [they]248-they all plodded on in silence .

[The shore]249-the shore that [they]248-they were walking on drew nearer and nearer to [the opposite shore]261-the opposite shore , and as [they]248-they came round [each promontory]262-each promontory [the children]254-the children expected to find the place where [the two]264-the two joined . But in this [they]248-they were disappointed . [They]248-they came to some rocks which [they]248-they had to climb and from the top [they]248-they could see a fair way ahead andâ€”"Oh bother ! "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund , " it 's no good . [We]248-they sha n't be able to get to [those other woods]1476-those other woods at all . [We]248-they 're on [an island]1475-an island ! "[71-edmund]

It was true . At this point [the channel between [them]248-they and [the opposite coast]266-the opposite coast]265-the channel between them and the opposite coast was only about thirty or forty yards wide ; but [they]248-they could now see that this was [its]265-the channel between them and the opposite coast narrowest place . After that , [[their]248-they own coast]267-their own coast bent round to the right again and [they]248-they could see open sea between [it]265-the channel between them and the opposite coast and [the mainland]268-the mainland . It was obvious that [they]248-they had already come much more than half - way round [the island]1468-the island .

" Look ! "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy suddenly . " What 's that ? "[72-lucy] [She]72-lucy pointed to a long silvery , snake - like thing that lay across [the beach]1466-the beach .

" [A stream]1478-a stream ! [A stream]1478-a stream ! "[271-the others] shouted [the others]271-the others , and , tired as [they]248-they were , [they]248-they lost no time in clattering down the rocks and racing to the fresh water . [They]248-they knew that [the stream]272-the stream would be better to drink farther up , away from [the beach]1466-the beach , so [they]248-they went at once to the spot where it came out of [the wood]252-the wood . The trees were as thick as ever , but [the stream]272-the stream had made itself a deep course between high mossy banks so that by stooping [you]276-you could follow it up in a sort of tunnel of leaves . [They]248-they dropped on [their]248-they knees by [the first brown , dimply pool]277-the first brown , dimply pool and drank and drank , and dipped [their]248-they faces in the water , and then dipped [their]248-they arms in up to the elbow .

" Now , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund , " what about those sandwiches ? "[71-edmund]

" Oh , had n't [we]248-they better save them ? "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan . " [We]248-they may need them far worse later on . "[70-susan]

" [I]72-lucy do wish , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy , " now that [we]248-they 're not thirsty , [we]248-they could go on feeling as not - hungry as [we]248-they did when [we]248-they were thirsty . "[72-lucy]

" But what about those sandwiches ? "[71-edmund] repeated [Edmund]71-edmund . " There 's no good saving [them]248-they till they go bad . [You]72-lucy 've got to remember it 's a good deal hotter here than in [England]2-england and [we]248-they 've been carrying them about in pockets for hours . "[71-edmund] So [they]248-they got out the two packets and divided them into four portions , and [nobody]278-nobody had quite enough , but it was a great deal better than nothing . Then [they]248-they talked about [their]248-they plans for the next meal . [Lucy]72-lucy wanted to go back to [the sea]244-the sea and catch shrimps , until [someone]1462-someone pointed out that [they]248-they had no nets . [Edmund]71-edmund said [they]248-they must gather gulls ' eggs from [the rocks]281-the rocks , but when [they]248-they came to think of it [they]248-they could n't remember having seen any gulls ' eggs and would n't be able to cook them if [they]248-they found any . [Peter]69-peter thought to [himself]69-peter that unless [they]248-they had some stroke of luck [they]248-they would soon be glad to eat eggs raw , but [he]69-peter did n't see any point in saying this out loud . [Susan]70-susan said it was a pity [they]248-they had eaten the sandwiches so soon . [One or two tempers]282-one or two tempers very nearly got lost at this stage . Finally [Edmund]71-edmund said :

" Look here . There 's only one thing to be done . [We]248-they must explore [the wood]252-the wood . [Hermits]1481-hermits and [knights]1482-knights - errant and [people like that]1483-people like that always manage to live somehow if [they]1483-people like that 're in [a forest]1484-a forest . [They]1483-people like that find roots and berries and things . "[71-edmund]

" What sort of roots ? "[70-susan] asked [Susan]70-susan .

" [I]72-lucy always thought it meant roots of trees , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy .

" Come on , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter , " [Ed]71-edmund is right . And [we]248-they must try to do something . And it 'll be better than going out into the glare and the sun again . "[69-peter]

So [they]248-they all got up and began to follow [the stream]272-the stream . It was very hard work . [They]248-they had to stoop under branches and climb over branches , and [they]248-they blundered through great masses of stuff like rhododendrons and tore [their]248-they clothes and got [their]248-they feet wet in the stream ; and still there was no noise at all except the noise of [the stream]272-the stream and the noises [they]248-they were making [themselves]248-they . [They]248-they were beginning to get very tired of it when [they]248-they noticed a delicious smell , and then a flash of bright colour high above [them]248-they at the top of [the right bank]285-the right bank .

" [I]72-lucy say ! "[72-lucy] exclaimed [Lucy]72-lucy . " [I]72-lucy do believe that 's an apple tree . "[72-lucy]

It was . [They]248-they panted up [the steep bank]286-the steep bank , forced [their]248-they way through some brambles , and found [themselves]248-they standing round an old tree that was heavy with large yellowish - golden apples as firm and juicy as [you]287-you could wish to see .

" And this is not the only tree , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund with [his]71-edmund mouth full of apple . " Look there â€” and there . "[71-edmund]

" Why , there are dozens of them , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan , throwing away the core of [her]70-susan first apple and picking [her]70-susan second . " This must have been [an orchard]1485-an orchard â€” long , long ago , before [the place]1486-the place went wild and [the wood]252-the wood grew up . "[70-susan]

" Then this was once [an inhabited island]1488-an inhabited island , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter .

" And what 's that ? "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy , pointing ahead .

" By [Jove]76-jove , it 's a wall , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " An old stone wall . "[69-peter]

Pressing [their]248-they way between the laden branches [they]248-they reached the wall . [It]288-it was very old , and broken down in places , with moss and wallflowers growing on [it]288-it , but [it]288-it was higher than all but the tallest trees . And when [they]248-they came quite close to [it]288-it [they]248-they found a great arch which must once have had a gate in it but was now almost filled up with the largest of all the apple trees . [They]248-they had to break some of the branches to get past , and when [they]248-they had done so [they]248-they all blinked because the daylight became suddenly much brighter . [They]248-they found [themselves]248-they in [a wide open place with walls all round [it]289-a wide open place with walls all round it]289-a wide open place with walls all round it . In here there were no trees , only level grass and daisies , and ivy , and grey walls . [It]289-a wide open place with walls all round it was a bright , secret , quiet place , and rather sad ; and [all four]290-all four stepped out into the middle of [it]289-a wide open place with walls all round it , glad to be able to straighten [their]290-all four backs and move [their]290-all four limbs freely .

" This was n't [a garden]1489-a garden , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan presently . " It was [a castle]1490-a castle and this must have been [the courtyard]1491-the courtyard . "[70-susan]

" [I]69-peter see what [you]69-peter mean , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " Yes . That is the remains of [a tower]1492-a tower . And there is what used to be a flight of steps going up to the top of the walls . And look at those other steps â€” the broad , shallow ones â€” going up to that doorway . It must have been the door into [the great hall]1493-the great hall . "[69-peter]

" Ages ago , by the look of it , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund .

" Yes , ages ago , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " [I]69-peter wish [we]290-all four could find out who [the people]1494-the people were that lived in [this castle]1495-this castle ; and how long ago . "[69-peter]

" It gives [me]72-lucy a queer feeling , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy .

" Does it , [Lu]72-lucy ? "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter , turning and looking hard at [her]72-lucy . " Because it does the same to [me]69-peter . It is the queerest thing that has happened this queer day . [I]69-peter wonder where [we]290-all four are and what it all means ? "[69-peter]

While [they]291-they were talking [they]291-they had crossed [the courtyard]1491-the courtyard and gone through the other doorway into what had once been [the hall]293-the hall . This was now very like [the courtyard]1491-the courtyard , for the roof had long since disappeared and [it]295-it was merely another space of grass and daisies , except that [it]295-it was shorter and narrower and the walls were higher . Across the far end there was a kind of terrace about three feet higher than the rest .

" [I]70-susan wonder , was it really [the hall]293-the hall ? "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan . " What that terrace kind of thing ? "[70-susan]

" But unfortunately without the feast , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund . " It 's getting late , [you]70-susan know . Look how long the shadows are . And have [you]70-susan noticed that it is n't so hot ? "[71-edmund]

" [We]290-all four shall need a camp fire if [we]290-all four 've got to spend the night here , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . " [I]69-peter 've got matches . Let 's go and see if [we]290-all four can collect some dry wood . "[69-peter]

[Everyone]230-everyone saw the sense of this , and for the next half - hour [they]230-everyone were busy . [The orchard through which [they]230-everyone had first come into [the ruins]298-the ruins]297-the orchard through which they had first come into the ruins turned out not to be [a good place for firewood]299-a good place for firewood . [They]230-everyone tried [the other side of [the castle]301-the castle]300-the other side of the castle , passing out of [the hall]293-the hall by a little side door into a maze of stony humps and hollows which must once have been passages and [smaller rooms]303-smaller rooms but was now all nettles and wild roses . Beyond this [they]230-everyone found a wide gap in the castle wall and stepped through [it]304-it into a wood of darker and bigger trees where [they]230-everyone found dead branches and rotten wood and sticks and dry leaves and fir - cones in plenty . [They]230-everyone went to and fro with bundles until [they]230-everyone had a good pile on the dais . At the fifth journey [they]230-everyone found the well , just outside [the hall]293-the hall , hidden in weeds , but clean and fresh and deep when [they]230-everyone had cleared these away . The remains of a stone pavement ran half - way round [it]306-it . Then [the girls]225-the girls went out to pick some more apples and [the boys]228-the boys built the fire , on the dais and fairly close to the corner between two walls , which [they]228-the boys thought would be the snuggest and warmest place . [They]230-everyone had great difficulty in lighting it and used a lot of matches , but [they]230-everyone succeeded in the end . Finally , [all four]290-all four sat down with [their]290-all four backs to the wall and [their]290-all four faces to the fire . [They]230-everyone tried roasting some of the apples on the ends of sticks . But roast apples are not much good without sugar , and they are too hot to eat with [your]310-your fingers till they are too cold to be worth eating . So [they]230-everyone had to content [themselves]230-everyone with raw apples , which , as [Edmund]71-edmund said , made [one]311-one realise that school suppers were n't so bad after allâ€”"I should n't mind a good thick slice of bread and margarine this minute , "[71-edmund] [he]71-edmund added . But the spirit of adventure was rising in [them]290-all four all , and [no one]216-no one really wanted to be back at [school]221-school .

Shortly after the last apple had been eaten , [Susan]70-susan went out to [the well]314-the well to get another drink . When [she]70-susan came back [she]70-susan was carrying something in [her]70-susan hand .

[All]1463-all now saw what it was â€” a little chess - knight , ordinary in size but extraordinarily heavy because it was made of pure gold ; and the eyes in the horse 's head were two tiny little rubies â€” or rather one was , for the other had been knocked out .

" Why ! [They]325-they tried to use long sticks as torches but this was not a success . If [you]326-you held them with the lighted end up [they]325-they went out , and if [you]326-you held them the other way [they]325-they scorched [your]326-you hand and the smoke got in [your]326-you eyes . In the end [they]325-they had to use [Edmund]71-edmund 's electric torch ; luckily it had been a birthday present less than a week ago and the battery was almost new . [He]71-edmund went first , with the light . Then came [Lucy]72-lucy , then [Susan]70-susan , and [Peter]69-peter brought up the rear .

" [I]71-edmund 've come to the top of the steps , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund .

" Then it really must be [Cair Paravel]4-cair paravel , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . " There were sixteen . "[72-lucy] Nothing more was said till all four were standing in a knot together at the foot of the stairway . Then [Edmund]71-edmund flashed [his]71-edmund torch slowly round .

" O â€” o â€” o â€” oh ! ! "[327-all the children] said [all the children]327-all the children at once .

For now all knew that it was indeed [the ancient treasure chamber of [Cair Paravel]4-cair paravel]328-the ancient treasure chamber of cair paravel where [they]325-they had once reigned as [Kings]213-kings and [Queens of [Narnia]1-narnia]330-queens of narnia . There was a kind of path up the middle ( as it might be in [a greenhouse]331-a greenhouse ) , and along each side at intervals stood rich suits of armour , like [knights guarding the treasures]332-knights guarding the treasures . In between the suits of armour , and on each side of [the path]333-the path , were shelves covered with precious things â€” necklaces and arm rings and finger rings and golden bowls and dishes and long tusks of ivory , brooches and coronets and chains of gold , and heaps of unset stones lying piled anyhow as if they were marbles or potatoes â€” diamonds , rubies , carbuncles , emeralds , topazes and amethysts . Under the shelves stood great chests of oak strengthened with iron bars and heavily padlocked . And it was bitterly cold , and so still that [they]325-they could hear [themselves]325-they breathing , and the treasures were so covered with dust that unless [they]325-they had realised where [they]325-they were and remembered most of the things , [they]325-they would hardly have known they were treasures . There was something sad and a little frightening about [the place]1486-the place , because it all seemed so forsaken and long ago . That was why [nobody]278-nobody said anything for at least a minute .

Then , of course , [they]325-they began walking about and picking things up to look at . It was like meeting [very old friends]336-very old friends . If [you]337-you had been [there]338-there [you]337-you would have heard [them]325-they saying things like , " Oh look ! [Our]325-they coronation rings â€” do [you]337-you remember first wearing this?â€”Why , this is the little brooch [we]325-they all thought was lost â€” [I]325-they say , is n't that the armour [you]337-you wore in the great tournament in [the Lone Islands?â€”do]8-the lone islands?â€”do [you]337-you remember [the dwarf]1552-the dwarf making that for me?â€”do [you]337-you remember drinking out of that horn?â€”do [you]337-you remember , do [you]337-you remember ? "[325-they]

But suddenly [Edmund]71-edmund said , " Look here . [We]325-they must n't waste the battery : goodness knows how often [we]325-they shall need it . Had n't [we]325-they better take what [we]325-they want and get out again ? "[71-edmund]

" [We]325-they must take the gifts , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter . For long ago at a Christmas in [Narnia]1-narnia [he]69-peter and [Susan]70-susan and [Lucy]72-lucy had been given certain presents which [they]339-they valued more than [[their]339-they whole kingdom]340-their whole kingdom . [Edmund]71-edmund had had no gift , because [he]71-edmund was not with [them]339-they at the time . ( This was [his]71-edmund own fault , and [you]341-you can read about it in the other book . )

[They]339-they all agreed with [Peter]69-peter and walked up the path to the wall at the far end of [the treasure chamber]1546-the treasure chamber , and there , sure enough , the gifts were still hanging . [Lucy]72-lucy 's was the smallest for it was only a little bottle . But the bottle was made of diamond instead of glass , and it was still more than half full of the magical cordial which would heal almost every wound and every illness . [Lucy]72-lucy said nothing and looked very solemn as [she]72-lucy took [her]72-lucy gift down from its place and slung the belt over [her]72-lucy shoulder and once more felt the bottle at [her]72-lucy side where it used to hang in the old days . [Susan]70-susan 's gift had been a bow and arrows and a horn . The bow was still there , and the ivory quiver , full of well - feathered arrows , butâ€”"Oh , [Susan]70-susan , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . " Where 's the horn ? "[72-lucy]

" Oh bother , bother , bother , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan after [she]70-susan had thought for a moment . " [I]70-susan remember now . [I]70-susan took it with [me]70-susan the last day of all , the day [we]1553-we went hunting [the White Stag]9-the white stag . It must have got lost when [we]1553-we blundered back into [that other place]1554-that other place â€” [England]2-england , [I]70-susan mean . "[70-susan]

[Edmund]71-edmund whistled . It was indeed a most shattering loss ; for this was an enchanted horn and , whenever [you]343-you blew it , help was certain to come to [you]343-you , wherever [you]343-you were .

" Just the sort of thing that might come in handy in [a place like this]1555-a place like this , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund .

" Never mind , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan , " [I]70-susan 've still got the bow . "[70-susan] And [she]70-susan took it .

" Wo n't the string be perished , [Su]77-su ? "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter .

But whether by some magic in the air of [the treasure chamber]1546-the treasure chamber or not , the bow was still in working order . Archery and swimming were the things [Susan]70-susan was good at . In a moment [she]70-susan had bent the bow and then [she]70-susan gave one little pluck to the string . It twanged : a chirruping twang that vibrated through [the whole room]345-the whole room . And that one small noise brought back the old days to [the children]254-the children 's minds more than anything that had happened yet . All the battles and hunts and feasts came rushing into [their]254-the children heads together .

Then [she]70-susan unstrung the bow again and slung the quiver at [her]70-susan side .

Next , [Peter]69-peter took down [his]69-peter gift â€” the shield with the great red lion on it , and the royal sword . [He]69-peter blew , and rapped [them]347-them on the floor , to get off the dust . [He]69-peter fitted the shield on [his]69-peter arm and slung the sword by [his]69-peter side . [He]69-peter was afraid at first that it might be rusty and stick to the sheath . But it was not so . With one swift motion [he]69-peter drew it and held it up , shining in the torchlight .

" It is [my]69-peter sword [Rhindon]82-rhindon , "[69-peter] [he]69-peter said ; " with it [I]69-peter killed [the Wolf]83-the wolf . "[69-peter] There was a new tone in [his]69-peter voice , and [the others all]348-the others all felt that [he]69-peter was really [Peter the High King]69-peter again . Then , after a little pause , [everyone]230-everyone remembered that [they]230-everyone must save the battery .

[They]230-everyone climbed the stair again and made up a good fire and lay down close together for warmth . [The ground]350-the ground was very hard and uncomfortable , but [they]230-everyone fell asleep in the end .

The worst of sleeping out of doors is that [you]351-you wake up so dreadfully early . And when [you]351-you wake [you]351-you have to get up because the ground is so hard that [you]351-you are uncomfortable . And it makes matters worse if there is nothing but apples for breakfast and [you]351-you have had nothing but apples for supper the night before . When [Lucy]72-lucy had said â€” truly enough â€” that it was a glorious morning , there did not seem to be anything else nice to be said . [Prince Caspian]91-prince caspian lived in [a great castle in [the centre of [Narnia]1-narnia]449-the centre of narnia with [[his]91-prince caspian uncle]1593-his uncle , [Miraz]92-miraz , [the King of [Narnia]1-narnia]451-the king of narnia]448-a great castle in the centre of narnia with his uncle , miraz , the king of narnia , and [[his]91-prince caspian aunt , who had red hair and was called Queen Prunaprismia]452-his aunt , who had red hair and was called queen prunaprismia . [He]87-caspian did not care much for [[his]87-caspian uncle]1593-his uncle and [aunt]460-aunt , but about twice a week [[his]87-caspian uncle]1593-his uncle would send for [him]87-caspian and [they]462-they would walk up and down together for half an hour on the terrace at [the south side of [the castle]301-the castle]463-the south side of the castle . " Ugh ! "[87-caspian] said [Caspian]87-caspian with a shudder . " Do [you]487-the doctor mean in [the Black Woods]22-the black woods ? Where all the â€” the â€” [you]487-the doctor know , [the ghosts]1737-the ghosts live ? "[87-caspian]

" [[Your]487-the doctor Highness]1646-your highness speaks as [you]487-the doctor have been taught , "[487-the doctor] said [the Doctor]487-the doctor . " But it is all lies . There are [no ghosts there]1739-no ghosts there . That is a story invented by [the Telmarines]99-the telmarines . [[Your]487-the doctor Kings]1740-your kings are in deadly fear of [the sea]244-the sea because [they]1740-your kings can never quite forget that in all stories [Aslan]95-aslan comes from over [the sea]244-the sea . "[487-the doctor]

After this , [Caspian]87-caspian and [[his]87-caspian Tutor]489-his tutor had many more secret conversations on [the top of [the Great Tower]20-the great tower]524-the top of the great tower , and at each conversation [Caspian]87-caspian learned more about [Old Narnia]13-old narnia , so that thinking and dreaming about the old days , and longing that [they]525-they might come back , filled nearly all [his]87-caspian spare hours . But of course [he]87-caspian had not many hours to spare , for now [his]87-caspian education was beginning in earnest . [He]87-caspian learned sword - fighting and riding , swimming and diving , how to shoot with the bow and play on the recorder and the theorbo , how to hunt the stag and cut [him]87-caspian up when [he]87-caspian was dead , besides Cosmography , Rhetoric , Heraldry , Versification , and of course History , with a little Law , Physic , Alchemy and Astronomy . " And [I]87-caspian [myself]87-caspian , "[87-caspian] [he]87-caspian added , " am only [a very imperfect magician]1761-a very imperfect magician and can do only the smallest experiments . "[87-caspian] Of Navigation ( " Which is a noble and heroical art , "[487-the doctor] said [the Doctor]487-the doctor ) [he]87-caspian was taught nothing , because [King Miraz]92-miraz disapproved of [ships]528-ships and [the sea]244-the sea .

[He]87-caspian also learned a great deal by using [his]87-caspian own eyes and ears . As [a little boy]530-a little boy [he]87-caspian had often wondered why [he]87-caspian disliked [[his]87-caspian aunt]531-his aunt , [Queen Prunaprismia]108-queen prunaprismia ; [he]87-caspian now saw that it was because [she]108-queen prunaprismia disliked [him]87-caspian . [He]87-caspian also began to see that [Narnia]1-narnia was [an unhappy country]532-an unhappy country . The taxes were high and the laws were stern and [Miraz]92-miraz was [a cruel man]533-a cruel man .

After some years there came a time when [the Queen]534-the queen seemed to be ill and there was a great deal of bustle and pother about [her]534-the queen in [the castle]301-the castle and [doctors]536-doctors came and [the courtiers]537-the courtiers whispered . This was in early summertime . " Ca n't [I]87-caspian get [my]87-caspian horse [Destrier]116-destrier ? "[87-caspian] said [Caspian]87-caspian .

During the long climb down [the winding staircase]556-the winding staircase [Cornelius]96-doctor cornelius whispered many more words of direction and advice . [Caspian]87-caspian 's heart was sinking , but [he]87-caspian tried to take it all in . Then came the fresh air in [the garden]1824-the garden , a fervent handclasp with [the Doctor]487-the doctor , a run across [the lawn]559-the lawn , a welcoming whinny from [Destrier]116-destrier , and so [King Caspian the Tenth]87-caspian left [the castle of [[his]87-caspian fathers]561-his fathers]560-the castle of his fathers . Looking back , [he]87-caspian saw fireworks going up to celebrate the birth of [the new prince]562-the new prince .

All night [he]87-caspian rode southward , choosing by - ways and bridle paths through [woods]563-woods as long as [he]87-caspian was in [country that [he]87-caspian knew]564-country that he knew ; but afterwards [he]87-caspian kept to [the high road]565-the high road . [Destrier]116-destrier was as excited as [[his]116-destrier master]566-his master at this unusual journey , and [Caspian]87-caspian , though tears had come into [his]87-caspian eyes at saying good - bye to [Doctor Cornelius]96-doctor cornelius , felt brave and , in a way , happy , to think that [he]87-caspian was [King Caspian]87-caspian riding to seek adventures , with [his]87-caspian sword on [his]87-caspian left hip and [Susan]70-susan 's magic horn on [his]87-caspian right . But when day came , with a sprinkle of rain , and [he]87-caspian looked about [him]87-caspian and saw on every side [unknown woods]567-unknown woods , [wild heaths]568-wild heaths and [blue mountains]569-blue mountains , [he]87-caspian thought how large and strange [the world]1697-the world was and felt frightened and small .

As soon as it was full daylight [he]87-caspian left [the road]571-the road and found an open grassy place amid a wood where [he]87-caspian could rest . [He]87-caspian took off [Destrier]116-destrier 's bridle and let [him]116-destrier graze , ate some cold chicken and drank a little wine , and presently fell asleep . It was late afternoon when [he]87-caspian awoke . [He]87-caspian ate a morsel and continued [his]87-caspian journey , still southward , by [many unfrequented lanes]572-many unfrequented lanes . [He]87-caspian was now in [a land of hills]573-a land of hills , going up and down , but always more up than down . From every ridge [he]87-caspian could see [the mountains]1713-the mountains growing bigger and blacker ahead . As the evening closed in , [he]87-caspian was riding [their lower slopes]575-their lower slopes . The wind rose . Soon rain fell in torrents . [Destrier]116-destrier became uneasy ; there was thunder in the air . And now [they]576-they entered [a dark and seemingly endless pine forest]577-a dark and seemingly endless pine forest , and all the stories [Caspian]87-caspian had ever heard of trees being unfriendly to [Man]117-man crowded into [his]87-caspian mind . [He]87-caspian remembered that [he]87-caspian was , after all , [a Telmarine]103-telmarine , [one of the race who cut down trees wherever [they]579-they could and were at war with all wild things]578-one of the race who cut down trees wherever they could and were at war with all wild things ; and though [he]87-caspian [himself]87-caspian might be unlike [other Telmarines]580-other telmarines , the trees could not be expected to know this .

Nor did [they]579-they . The wind became a tempest , [the woods]415-the woods roared and creaked all round [him]87-caspian . There came a crash . A tree fell right across [the road]571-the road just behind [him]87-caspian . " Quiet , [Destrier]116-destrier , quiet ! "[87-caspian] said [Caspian]87-caspian , patting [his]87-caspian horse 's neck ; but [he]87-caspian was trembling [himself]87-caspian and knew that [he]87-caspian had escaped death by an inch . Lightning flashed and a great crack of thunder seemed to break the sky in two just overhead . [Destrier]116-destrier bolted in good earnest . [Caspian]87-caspian was [a good rider]583-a good rider , but [he]87-caspian had not the strength to hold [him]116-destrier back . [He]87-caspian kept [his]87-caspian seat , but [he]87-caspian knew that [his]87-caspian life hung by a thread during the wild career that followed . Tree after tree rose up before [them]584-we in the dusk and was only just avoided . Then , almost too suddenly to hurt ( and yet it did hurt [him]87-caspian too ) something struck [Caspian]87-caspian on the forehead and [he]87-caspian knew no more .

When [he]87-caspian came to [himself]87-caspian [he]87-caspian was lying in a firelit place with bruised limbs and a bad headache . Low voices were speaking close at hand .

" And now , "[311-one] said [one]311-one , " before it wakes up [we]584-we must decide what to do with it . "[311-one]

" Kill [it]1827-it , "[586-another] said [another]586-another . " [We]584-we ca n't let [it]1827-it live . [It]1827-it would betray [us]584-we . "[586-another]

" [We]584-we ought to have killed [it]1827-it at once , or else let [it]1827-it alone , "[587-a third voice] said [a third voice]587-a third voice . " [We]584-we ca n't kill [it]1827-it now . " [Gentlemen]1829-gentlemen , "[87-caspian] said [Caspian]87-caspian in a feeble voice , " whatever [you]1829-gentlemen do to [me]87-caspian , [I]87-caspian hope [you]1829-gentlemen will be kind to [my]87-caspian poor horse . "[87-caspian]

" [Your]588-the first voice horse had taken flight long before [we]584-we found [you]588-the first voice , "[588-the first voice] said [the first voice]588-the first voice â€” a curiously husky , earthy voice , as [Caspian]87-caspian now noticed .

" Now do n't let [it]1827-it talk [you]87-caspian round with its pretty words , "[589-the second voice] said [the second voice]589-the second voice . " [I]589-the second voice still say â€” â€” "[589-the second voice]

" Horns and halibuts ! "[590-the third voice] exclaimed [the third voice]590-the third voice . " Of course [we]584-we 're not going to murder [it]1827-it . For shame , [Nikabrik]118-nikabrik . " [I]588-the first voice shall give [it]1827-it a drink , "[588-the first voice] said [the first voice]588-the first voice , presumably [Trufflehunter]119-trufflehunter 's . A dark shape approached the bed . [Caspian]87-caspian felt an arm slipped gently under [his]87-caspian shoulders â€” if it was exactly an arm . The shape somehow seemed wrong . The face that bent towards [him]87-caspian seemed wrong too . [He]87-caspian got the impression that it was very hairy and very long nosed , and there were odd white patches on each side of it . " It 's a mask of some sort , "[87-caspian] thought [Caspian]87-caspian . " Or perhaps [I]87-caspian 'm in a fever and imagining it all . "[87-caspian] A cupful of something sweet and hot was set to [his]87-caspian lips and [he]87-caspian drank . At that moment one of [the others]271-the others poked the fire . A blaze sprang up and [Caspian]87-caspian almost screamed with the shock as the sudden light revealed the face that was looking into [his]87-caspian own . It was not [a man]1682-a man 's face but a badger 's , though larger and friendlier and more intelligent than the face of [any badger [he]87-caspian had seen before]594-any badger he had seen before . And it had certainly been talking . [He]87-caspian saw , too , that [he]87-caspian was on a bed of heather , in [a cave]595-a cave . By the fire sat [two little bearded men]596-two little bearded men , so much wilder and shorter and hairier and thicker than [Doctor Cornelius]96-doctor cornelius that [he]87-caspian knew [them]596-two little bearded men at once for real [Dwarfs]99-the telmarines , [ancient Dwarfs with not a drop of human blood in [their]99-the telmarines veins]597-ancient dwarfs with not a drop of human blood in their veins . And [Caspian]87-caspian knew that [he]87-caspian had found [the Old Narnians]88-the old narnians at last . Then [his]87-caspian head began to swim again .

In the next few days [he]87-caspian learned to know [them]596-two little bearded men by names . " Long live [the King]1497-the king , "[130-glenstorm] [he]130-glenstorm cried . " [I]130-glenstorm and [[my]130-glenstorm sons]1894-my sons are ready for war . When is the battle to be joined ? "[130-glenstorm]

Up till now neither [Caspian]87-caspian nor [the others]271-the others had really been thinking of a war . But , in the main , [they]648-they had thought only of living to [themselves]648-they in [woods and caves]661-woods and caves and building up an attempt at [Old Narnia]13-old narnia in hiding . "[130-glenstorm] [He]130-glenstorm spoke in such a voice that neither [Caspian]87-caspian nor [the others]271-the others hesitated for a moment : it now seemed to [them]665-they quite possible that [they]665-they might win a war and quite certain that [they]665-they must wage one .

As it was now past the middle of the day , [they]665-they rested with [the Centaurs]133-the centaurs and ate such food as [the Centaurs]133-the centaurs provided â€” cakes of oaten meal , and apples , and herbs , and wine , and cheese .

[The next place [they]665-they were to visit]666-the next place they were to visit was quite near at hand , but [they]665-they had to go a long way round in order to avoid [a region in which [Men]1691-men lived]667-a region in which men lived . There [Trufflehunter]119-trufflehunter called at the mouth of [a little hole in [a green bank]671-a green bank]670-a little hole in a green bank and out popped the last thing [Caspian]87-caspian expected â€” [a Talking Mouse]134-the mouse . [He]134-the mouse was of course bigger than a common mouse , well over a foot high when [he]134-the mouse stood on [his]134-the mouse hind legs , and with ears nearly as long ( though broader ) than a rabbit 's . [His]134-the mouse name was [Reepicheep]135-reepicheep and [he]134-the mouse was a gay and martial mouse . [He]134-the mouse wore a tiny little rapier at [his]134-the mouse side and twirled [his]134-the mouse long whiskers as if they were a moustache . "[134-the mouse] [Caspian]87-caspian tried hard ( and successfully ) not to laugh , but [he]87-caspian could n't help thinking that [Reepicheep]135-reepicheep and all [[his]135-reepicheep people]672-his people could very easily be put in a washing basket and carried [home]1559-home on one 's back .

[The Badger]120-the badger only grunted at this , and after that there was such a silence that [Caspian]87-caspian had nearly dropped off to sleep when [he]87-caspian thought [he]87-caspian heard a faint musical sound from [the depth of [the woods]415-the woods at [his]87-caspian back]679-the depth of the woods at his back . Then [he]87-caspian thought it was only a dream and turned over again ; but as soon as [his]87-caspian ear touched [the ground]350-the ground [he]87-caspian felt or heard ( it was hard to tell which ) a faint beating or drumming . [He]87-caspian raised [his]87-caspian head . The beating noise at once became fainter , but the music returned , clearer this time . It was like flutes . [He]87-caspian saw that [Trufflehunter]119-trufflehunter was sitting up staring into the wood . The moon was bright ; [Caspian]87-caspian had been asleep longer than [he]87-caspian thought . Nearer and nearer came the music , a tune wild and yet dreamy , and the noise of many light feet , till at last , out from the wood into the moonlight , came dancing shapes such as [Caspian]87-caspian had been thinking of all [his]87-caspian life . [They]682-they were not much taller than [Dwarfs]99-the telmarines , but far slighter and more graceful . [Their]682-they curly heads had little horns , the upper part of [their]682-they bodies gleamed naked in the pale light , but [their]682-they legs and feet were those of goats .

" [Fauns]99-the telmarines ! "[87-caspian] cried [Caspian]87-caspian , jumping up , and in a moment [they]682-they were all round [him]87-caspian . [The place where [they]682-they had met [the Fauns]99-the telmarines]686-the place where they had met the fauns was , of course , Dancing Lawn itself , and here [Caspian]87-caspian and [[his]87-caspian friends]687-his friends remained till the night of the Great Council . It was after [they]1463-all had taken up [[their]1463-all quarters]730-their quarters in and around [the How that fortune]731-the how that fortune began to turn against [them]1463-all . [[King Miraz]92-miraz 's scouts]732-king miraz 's scouts soon found [[their]1463-all new lair]733-their new lair , and [he]92-miraz and [[his]92-miraz army]1937-his army arrived on [the edge of [the woods]415-the woods]735-the edge of the woods . And as so often happens , [the enemy]1949-the enemy turned out stronger than [they]1463-all had reckoned . [Caspian]87-caspian 's heart sank as [he]87-caspian saw [company]738-company after [company]738-company arriving . And though [[Miraz]92-miraz 's men]740-miraz 's men may have been afraid of going into [the wood]252-the wood , [they]740-miraz 's men were even more afraid of [Miraz]92-miraz , and with [him]92-miraz in command [they]740-miraz 's men carried battle deeply into it and sometimes almost to the How itself . [Caspian]87-caspian and [other captains of course]742-other captains of course made many sorties into [the open country]743-the open country . Thus there was fighting on most days and sometimes by night as well ; but [[Caspian]87-caspian 's party]744-caspian 's party had on the whole the worst of it .

At last there came a night when everything had gone as badly as possible , and the rain which had been falling heavily all day had ceased at nightfall only to give place to raw cold . That morning [Caspian]87-caspian had arranged what was [his]87-caspian biggest battle yet , and [all]1463-all had hung [their]1463-all hopes on it . [He]87-caspian , with [most of [the Dwarfs]617-the dwarfs]746-most of the dwarfs , was to have fallen on [the King]1497-the king 's right wing at daybreak , and then , when [they]740-miraz 's men were heavily engaged , [Giant Wimbleweather]149-giant wimbleweather , with the Centaurs and some of the fiercest beasts , was to have broken out from another place and endeavoured to cut [the King]1497-the king 's right off from the rest of [the army]750-the army . But it had all failed . [No one]216-no one had warned [Caspian]87-caspian ( because [no one]216-no one in these later days of [Narnia]1-narnia remembered ) that [Giants]150-giants are not at all clever . [Poor Wimbleweather]149-giant wimbleweather , though as brave as a lion , was [a true Giant]753-a true giant in that respect . [He]149-giant wimbleweather had broken out at the wrong time and from [the wrong place]754-the wrong place , and both [[his]149-giant wimbleweather party]755-his party and [Caspian]87-caspian 's had suffered badly and done [the enemy]1949-the enemy little harm . The best of the Bears had been hurt , [a Centaur]757-a centaur terribly wounded , and there were [few in [[Caspian]87-caspian 's party]744-caspian 's party who had not lost blood]758-few in caspian 's party who had not lost blood . It was a gloomy company that huddled under the dripping trees to eat [their]760-their scanty supper .

The gloomiest of all was [Giant Wimbleweather]149-giant wimbleweather . [He]149-giant wimbleweather knew it was all [his]149-giant wimbleweather fault . [He]149-giant wimbleweather sat in silence shedding big tears which collected on the end of [his]149-giant wimbleweather nose and then fell off with a huge splash on the whole bivouac of the Mice , who had just been beginning to get warm and drowsy . [They]761-they all jumped up , shaking the water out of [their]761-they ears and wringing [their]761-they little blankets , and asked [the Giant]762-the giant in shrill but forcible voices whether [he]762-the giant thought [they]761-they were n't wet enough without this sort of thing . [And Wimbleweather]149-giant wimbleweather tiptoed away to find some place where [he]149-giant wimbleweather could be miserable in peace and stepped on [somebody]1543-somebody 's tail and [somebody]1543-somebody ( [they]761-they said afterwards it was a fox ) bit [him]149-giant wimbleweather . And so [everyone]230-everyone was out of temper .

But in [the secret and magical chamber at the heart of [the How]770-the how]769-the secret and magical chamber at the heart of the how , [King Caspian]87-caspian , with [Cornelius]96-doctor cornelius and [the Badger]120-the badger and [Nikabrik]118-nikabrik and [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin , were at council . Thick pillars of ancient workmanship supported the roof . [They]761-they were not using the Table nor sitting round [it]772-it : it was too magic a thing for any common use . " It 's a dangerous game , "[121-trumpkin] said [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin . " But since [you]2052-lad make such a point of it , [I]121-trumpkin 'll try a pass or two . "[121-trumpkin]

Both swords were out in a moment and [the three others]795-the three others jumped off the dais and stood watching . It was well worth it . It was not like the silly fighting [you]796-you see with broad swords on the stage . It was not even like the rapier fighting which [you]796-you sometimes see rather better done . This was real broad - sword fighting . The great thing is to slash at [[your]796-you enemy]797-your enemy 's legs and feet because they are the part that have no armour . And when [he]797-your enemy slashes at [yours]796-you [you]796-you jump with both feet off the ground so that [his]797-your enemy blow goes under them . This gave [the Dwarf]1552-the dwarf an advantage because [Edmund]71-edmund , being much taller , had to be always stooping . [I]0-i do n't think [Edmund]71-edmund would have had a chance if [he]71-edmund had fought [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin twenty - four hours earlier . [He]71-edmund was [Edmund]71-edmund once more . And soon [the green , wooded coast of [the island]1468-the island]834-the green , wooded coast of the island was falling away behind [them]254-the children , and [[its]834-the green , wooded coast of the island little bays and headlands]836-its little bays and headlands were beginning to look flatter , and [the boat]374-the boat was rising and falling in the gentle swell . [The sea]244-the sea began to grow bigger around [them]254-the children and , in the distance , bluer , but close round [the boat]374-the boat it was green and bubbly . Everything smelled salt and there was no noise except the swishing of water and the clop - clop of water against the sides and the splash of the oars and the jolting noise of the rowlocks . The sun grew hot .

It was delightful for [Lucy]72-lucy and [Susan]70-susan in the bows , bending over the edge and trying to get [their]254-the children hands in [the sea]244-the sea which [they]254-the children could never quite reach . " It 's like old times , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . " Do [you]70-susan remember [our]2068-we voyage to [Terebinthia]49-terebinthia â€” and [Galma]50-galma â€” and [Seven Isles]51-seven isles â€” and [the Lone Islands]52-the lone islands ? "[72-lucy]

[Presently Susan]70-susan took over [Edmund]71-edmund 's oar and [he]71-edmund came forward to join [Lucy]72-lucy . [They]841-they had passed [the island]1468-the island now and stood closer in to [the shore]249-the shore â€” all wooded and deserted . " Phew ! This is pretty gruelling work , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter .

" Ca n't [I]72-lucy row for a bit ? "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy .

" The oars are too big for [you]70-susan , "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter shortly , not because [he]69-peter was cross but because [he]69-peter had no strength to spare for talking .

[Susan]70-susan and [the two boys]793-the two boys were bitterly tired with rowing before [they]841-they rounded [the last headland]846-the last headland and began the final pull up Glasswater itself , and [Lucy]72-lucy 's head ached from the long hours of sun and the glare on the water . [Even Trumpkin]121-trumpkin longed for the voyage to be over . The seat on which [he]121-trumpkin sat to steer had been made for [men]1691-men , not [Dwarfs]478-dwarfs , and [his]121-trumpkin feet did not reach the floor - boards ; and [everyone]230-everyone knows how uncomfortable that is even for ten minutes . And as [they]841-they all grew more tired , [their]841-they spirits fell . Up till now [the children]254-the children had only been thinking of how to get to [Caspian]87-caspian . Now [they]254-the children wondered what [they]254-the children would do when [they]254-the children found [him]87-caspian , and how a handful of [Dwarfs]478-dwarfs and [woodland creatures]852-woodland creatures could defeat [an army of [grown - up Humans]854-grown - up humans]853-an army of grown - up humans .

Twilight was coming on as [they]841-they rowed slowly up [the windings of [Glasswater Creek]46-glasswater creek]855-the windings of glasswater creek â€” a twilight which deepened as the banks drew closer together and the overhanging trees began almost to meet overhead . It was very quiet in [here]1474-here as the sound of [the sea]244-the sea died away behind [them]841-they ; [they]841-they could even hear the trickle of [the little streams that poured down from [the forest]606-the forest into [Glasswater]47-glasswater]858-the little streams that poured down from the forest into glasswater .

[They]841-they went ashore at last , far too tired to attempt lighting a fire ; and even a supper of apples ( though most of [them]841-they felt that [they]841-they never wanted to see an apple again ) seemed better than trying to catch or shoot anything . After a little silent munching [they]841-they all huddled down together in the moss and dead leaves between four large beech trees .

[[Everyone]230-everyone except [Lucy]72-lucy]861-everyone except lucy went to sleep at once . [Lucy]72-lucy , being far less tired , found it hard to get comfortable . Also , [she]72-lucy had forgotten till now that all [Dwarfs]99-the telmarines snore . [She]72-lucy knew that one of the best ways of getting to sleep is to stop trying , so [she]72-lucy opened [her]72-lucy eyes . Through a gap in the bracken and branches [she]72-lucy could just see a patch of water in [the Creek]48-the creek and the sky above [it]48-the creek . Then , with a thrill of memory , [she]72-lucy saw again , after all those years , the bright Narnian stars . [She]72-lucy had once known them better than the stars of [[our]862-our own world]863-our own world , because as [a Queen in [Narnia]1-narnia]864-a queen in narnia [she]72-lucy had gone to bed much later than as [a child]821-a child in [England]2-england . And there [they]866-they were â€” at least , three of the summer constellations could be seen from where [she]72-lucy lay : [the Ship]867-the ship , [the Hammer]158-the hammer , and the Leopard . " [Dear old Leopard]159-dear old leopard , "[72-lucy] [she]72-lucy murmured happily to [herself]72-lucy .

Instead of getting drowsier [she]72-lucy was getting more awake â€” with an odd , night - time , dreamish kind of wakefulness . [The Creek]48-the creek was growing brighter . [She]72-lucy knew now that the moon was on it , though [she]72-lucy could n't see the moon . And now [she]72-lucy began to feel that [the whole forest]868-the whole forest was coming awake like [herself]72-lucy . Hardly knowing why [she]72-lucy did it , [she]72-lucy got up quickly and walked a little distance away from [their]869-their bivouac .

" This is lovely , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy to [herself]72-lucy . It was cool and fresh ; delicious smells were floating everywhere . [Somewhere close by]870-somewhere close by [she]72-lucy heard the twitter of [a nightingale]871-a nightingale beginning to sing , then stopping , then beginning again . It was a little lighter ahead . [She]72-lucy went towards the light and came to a place where there were fewer trees , and whole patches or pools of moonlight , but the moonlight and the shadows so mixed that [you]872-you could hardly be sure where anything was or what it was . At the same moment [the nightingale]873-the nightingale , satisfied at last with [his]873-the nightingale tuning up , burst into full song .

[Lucy]72-lucy 's eyes began to grow accustomed to the light , and [she]72-lucy saw the trees that were nearest [her]72-lucy more distinctly . A great longing for the old days when the trees could talk in [Narnia]1-narnia came over [her]72-lucy . [She]72-lucy knew exactly how each of these trees would talk if only [she]72-lucy could wake [them]874-you , and what sort of human form it would put on . [She]72-lucy looked at a silver birch : it would have a soft , showery voice and would look like [a slender girl]875-a slender girl , with hair blown all about [her]875-a slender girl face , and fond of dancing . [She]72-lucy looked at the oak : [he]876-he would be [a wizened , but hearty old man with a frizzled beard and warts on [his]876-he face and hands , and hair growing out of the warts]877-a wizened , but hearty old man with a frizzled beard and warts on his face and hands , and hair growing out of the warts . [She]72-lucy looked at the beech under which [she]72-lucy was standing . Ah!â€”she would be the best of all . [She]72-lucy would be [a gracious goddess]878-a gracious goddess , smooth and stately , [the lady of the wood]879-the lady of the wood .

" Oh , Trees , Trees , Trees , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy ( though [she]72-lucy had not been intending to speak at all ) . " Oh , Trees , wake , wake , wake . Do n't [you]874-you remember it ? Do n't [you]874-you remember [me]72-lucy ? Dryads and Hamadryads , come out , come to [me]72-lucy . "[72-lucy]

Though there was not a breath of wind [they]874-you all stirred about [her]72-lucy . The rustling noise of the leaves was almost like words . [The nightingale]873-the nightingale stopped singing as if to listen to it . [Lucy]72-lucy felt that at any moment [she]72-lucy would begin to understand what the trees were trying to say . But the moment did not come . The rustling died away . [The nightingale]873-the nightingale resumed its song . Even in the moonlight the wood looked more ordinary again . Yet [Lucy]72-lucy had the feeling ( as [you]882-you sometimes have when [you]882-you are trying to remember a name or a date and almost get it , but it vanishes before [you]882-you really do ) that [she]72-lucy had just missed something : as if [she]72-lucy had spoken to the trees a split second too soon or a split second too late , or used all the right words except one , or put in one word that was just wrong .

Quite suddenly [she]72-lucy began to feel tired . [She]72-lucy went back to the bivouac , snuggled down between [Susan]70-susan and [Peter]69-peter , and was asleep in a few minutes .

It was a cold and cheerless waking for [them]874-you all next morning , with a grey twilight in [the wood]252-the wood ( for the sun had not yet risen ) and everything damp and dirty .

" [Apples]160-apples , heigh - ho , "[121-trumpkin] said [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin with a rueful grin . " [I]121-trumpkin must say [[you]874-you ancient kings]2093-you ancient kings and [queens]214-queens do n't overfeed [[your]874-you courtiers]2095-your courtiers ! "[121-trumpkin]

[They]874-you stood up and shook [themselves]874-you and looked about . The trees were thick and [they]874-you could see no more than a few yards in any direction .

" [I]1552-the dwarf suppose [[your]874-you Majesties]2067-your majesties know the way all right ? "[1552-the dwarf] said [the Dwarf]1552-the dwarf .

" [I]70-susan do n't , "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan . " [I]70-susan 've never seen [these woods]1571-these woods in [my]70-susan life before . In fact [I]70-susan thought all along that [we]2098-we ought to have gone by [the river]363-the river . "[70-susan]

" Then [I]69-peter think [you]69-peter might have said so at the time , "[69-peter] answered [Peter]69-peter , with pardonable sharpness .

" Oh , do n't take any notice of [her]2100-her , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund . " [She]2100-her always is a wet blanket . So [they]910-they set off to [their]910-they right along the edge , downstream . And [Lucy]72-lucy came last of [the party]891-the party , crying bitterly .

To keep along [the edge of [the gorge]2123-the gorge]912-the edge of the gorge was not so easy as it had looked . Before [they]910-they had gone many yards [they]910-they were confronted with young fir woods growing on the very edge , and after [they]910-they had tried to go through these , stooping and pushing for about ten minutes , [they]910-they realised that , in there , it would take [them]910-they an hour to do half a mile . So [they]910-they came back and out again and decided to go round [the fir wood]914-the fir wood . This took [them]910-they much farther to [their]910-they right than [they]910-they wanted to go , far out of sight of [the cliffs]915-the cliffs and out of sound of [the river]363-the river , till [they]910-they began to be afraid [they]910-they had lost it altogether . [Nobody]278-nobody knew the time , but it was getting to the hottest part of the day .

When [they]910-they were able at last to go back to [the edge of [the gorge]2123-the gorge]912-the edge of the gorge ( nearly a mile below [the point from which [they]910-they had started]920-the point from which they had started ) [they]910-they found the cliffs on [[their]910-they side of [it]2123-the gorge]921-their side of it a good deal lower and more broken . Soon [they]910-they found a way down into [the gorge]2123-the gorge and continued the journey at [the river]363-the river 's edge . But first [they]910-they had a rest and a long drink . [No one]216-no one was talking any more about breakfast , or even dinner , with [Caspian]87-caspian .

[They]910-they may have been wise to stick to [the Rush]55-the rush instead of going along [the top]925-the top . It kept [them]910-they sure of [their]910-they direction : and ever since [the fir wood]914-the fir wood [they]910-they had all been afraid of being forced too far out of [their]910-they course and losing [themselves]910-they in [the wood]252-the wood . [It]914-the fir wood was [an old and pathless forest]928-an old and pathless forest , and [you]929-you could not keep anything like a straight course in [it]914-the fir wood . [Patches of hopeless brambles]930-patches of hopeless brambles , fallen trees , [boggy places]931-boggy places and dense undergrowth would be always getting in [your]929-you way . But [the gorge of [the Rush]55-the rush]932-the gorge of the rush was not at all a nice place for travelling either . [I]0-i mean , [it]932-the gorge of the rush was not a nice place for [people in a hurry]933-people in a hurry . For an afternoon 's ramble ending in a picnic tea it would have been delightful . [It]932-the gorge of the rush had everything [you]929-you could want on an occasion of that sort â€” [rumbling waterfalls]934-rumbling waterfalls , silver cascades , [deep , amber - coloured pools]935-deep , amber - coloured pools , mossy rocks , and deep moss on the banks in which [you]929-you could sink over [your]929-you ankles , every kind of fern , jewel - like dragon flies , sometimes a hawk overhead and once ( [Peter]69-peter and [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin both thought ) an eagle . But of course what [the children]254-the children and [the Dwarf]1552-the dwarf wanted to see as soon as possible was [the Great River below [them]939-they]938-the great river below them , and [Beruna]43-beruna , and the way to [Aslan]95-aslan 's How .

As [they]939-they went on , [the Rush]55-the rush began to fall more and more steeply . [Their]939-they journey became more and more of a climb and less and less of a walk â€” in places even a dangerous climb over slippery rock with a nasty drop into dark chasms , and [the river]363-the river roaring angrily at the bottom .

[You]929-you may be sure [they]939-they watched the cliffs on [their]939-they left eagerly for any sign of a break or any place where [they]939-they could climb [them]941-them ; but [those cliffs]942-those cliffs remained cruel . It was maddening , because [everyone]230-everyone knew that if once [they]939-they were out of [the gorge on that side]944-the gorge on that side , [they]939-they would have only a smooth slope and a fairly short walk to [[Caspian]87-caspian 's headquarters]945-caspian 's headquarters .

[The boys]228-the boys and [the Dwarf]1552-the dwarf were now in favour of lighting a fire and cooking [their]939-they bear - meat . [Susan]70-susan did n't want this ; [she]70-susan only wanted , as [she]70-susan said , " to get on and finish it and get out of [these beastly woods]2146-these beastly woods "[70-susan] . [Lucy]72-lucy was far too tired and miserable to have any opinion about anything . But as there was no dry wood to be had , it mattered very little what [anyone]217-anyone thought . [The boys]228-the boys began to wonder if raw meat was really as nasty as [they]228-the boys had always been told . [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin assured [them]228-the boys it was .

Of course , if [the children]254-the children had attempted a journey like this a few days ago in [England]2-england , [they]254-the children would have been knocked up . [I]0-i think [I]0-i have explained before how [Narnia]1-narnia was altering [them]254-the children . Even [Lucy]72-lucy was by now , so to speak , only one - third of [a little girl]951-a little girl going to [boarding school]233-boarding school for the first time , and [two - thirds of [Lucy]72-lucy]953-two - thirds of lucy .

" At last ! "[70-susan] said [Susan]70-susan .

" Oh , hurray ! "[69-peter] said [Peter]69-peter .

[The river gorge]954-the river gorge had just made a bend and the whole view spread out beneath [them]228-the boys . " By [Jove]76-jove , "[71-edmund] said [Edmund]71-edmund . " [We]228-the boys fought the Battle of [Beruna]43-beruna just where [that town]2147-that town is ! "[71-edmund]

This cheered [the boys]228-the boys more than anything . [They]228-the boys were all getting on at a quicker pace now . The going became easier . Soon it was no longer [a gorge]2119-a gorge at all , only [a valley]968-a valley . There were [no more waterfalls]969-no more waterfalls and presently [they]228-the boys were in fairly thick woods again .

Then â€” all at once â€” whizz , and a sound rather like the stroke of a woodpecker . [The children]254-the children were still wondering where ( ages ago ) [they]254-the children had heard a sound just like that and why [they]254-the children disliked it so , when [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin shouted , " Down , "[121-trumpkin] at the same moment forcing [Lucy]72-lucy ( who happened to be next to [him]121-trumpkin ) flat down into the bracken . [Peter]69-peter , who had been looking up to see if [he]69-peter could spot a squirrel , had seen what it was â€” a long cruel arrow had sunk into a tree trunk just above [his]69-peter head . As [he]69-peter pulled [Susan]70-susan down and dropped [himself]69-peter , another came rasping over [his]69-peter shoulder and struck the ground at [his]69-peter side .

" Quick ! Quick ! Get back ! Crawl ! "[121-trumpkin] panted [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin .

[They]228-the boys turned and wriggled along uphill , under the bracken , amid clouds of horribly buzzing flies . Arrows whizzed round [them]228-the boys . [One]166-one struck [Susan]70-susan 's helmet with a sharp ping and glanced off . [They]228-the boys crawled quicker . Sweat poured off [them]228-the boys . Then [they]228-the boys ran , stooping nearly double . [The boys]228-the boys held [their]228-the boys swords in [their]228-the boys hands for fear [they]228-the boys would trip [them]228-the boys up .

It was heart - breaking work â€” all uphill again , back over the ground [they]228-the boys had already travelled . When [they]228-the boys felt that [they]228-the boys really could n't run any more , even to save [their]228-the boys lives , [they]228-the boys all dropped down in the damp moss beside [a waterfall]972-a waterfall and behind a big boulder , panting . [They]228-the boys were surprised to see how high [they]228-the boys had already got .

[They]228-the boys listened intently and heard no sound of pursuit .

" And as soon as [we]228-the boys 're well up into [the forest]606-the forest , "[121-trumpkin] said [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin , " whatever [anyone]217-anyone says , [I]121-trumpkin 'm going to light a fire and cook supper . But [we]228-the boys must get well away from here . "[121-trumpkin]

There is no need to describe how [they]974-they toiled back up [the gorge]2123-the gorge . It was pretty hard work , but oddly enough [everyone]230-everyone felt more cheerful . [They]974-they were getting [their]974-they second wind ; and the word supper had had a wonderful effect .

[They]974-they reached the fir wood which had caused [them]974-they so much trouble while it was still daylight , and bivouacked in [a hollow just above [it]978-it]977-a hollow just above it . It was tedious gathering the fire wood ; but it was grand when the fire blazed up and [they]974-they began producing the damp and smeary parcels of bear - meat which would have been so very unattractive to [anyone who had spent the day indoors]979-anyone who had spent the day indoors . [The Dwarf]1552-the dwarf had splendid ideas about cookery . Each apple ( [they]974-they still had a few of these ) was wrapped up in bear 's meat â€” as if it was to be apple dumpling with meat instead of pastry , only much thicker â€” and spiked on a sharp stick and then roasted . And the juice of the apple worked all through the meat , like apple sauce with roast pork . Bear that has lived too much on other animals is not very nice , but bear that has had plenty of honey and fruit is excellent , and this turned out to be that sort of bear . It was a truly glorious meal . And , of course , no washing up â€” only lying back and watching the smoke from [Trumpkin]121-trumpkin 's pipe and stretching [one]311-one 's tired legs and chatting . [Everyone]230-everyone felt quite hopeful now about finding [King Caspian]87-caspian to - morrow and defeating [Miraz]92-miraz in a few days . It may not have been sensible of [them]974-they to feel like this , but [they]974-they did .

[They]974-they dropped off to sleep one by one , but all pretty quickly .

[Lucy]72-lucy woke out of the deepest sleep [you]983-you can imagine , with the feeling that the voice [she]72-lucy liked best in [the world]1697-the world had been calling [her]72-lucy name . [She]72-lucy thought at first it was [[her]72-lucy father]985-her father 's voice , but that did not seem quite right . Then [she]72-lucy thought it was [Peter]69-peter 's voice , but that did not seem to fit either . [She]72-lucy did not want to get up ; not because [she]72-lucy was still tired â€” on the contrary [she]72-lucy was wonderfully rested and all the aches had gone from [her]72-lucy bones â€” but because [she]72-lucy felt so extremely happy and comfortable . [She]72-lucy was looking straight up at the Narnian moon , which is larger than ours , and at the starry sky , for the place where [they]974-they had bivouacked was comparatively open .

" [Lucy]72-lucy , "[985-her father] came the call again , neither [[her]72-lucy father]985-her father 's voice nor [Peter]69-peter 's . [She]72-lucy sat up , trembling with excitement but not with fear . The moon was so bright that the whole forest landscape around [her]72-lucy was almost as clear as day , though it looked wilder . Behind [her]72-lucy was the fir wood ; away to [her]72-lucy right the jagged cliff - tops on [the far side of [the gorge]2123-the gorge]987-the far side of the gorge ; straight ahead , open grass to where [a glade of trees]989-a glade of trees began about a bow - shot away . [Lucy]72-lucy looked very hard at the trees of [that glade]990-that glade .

" Why , [I]72-lucy do believe [they]992-they 're moving , "[72-lucy] [she]72-lucy said to [[her]72-lucy self]991-her self . " [They]992-they 're walking about . "[72-lucy]

[She]72-lucy got up , [her]72-lucy heart beating wildly , and walked towards [them]992-they . There was certainly a noise in [the glade]993-the glade , a noise such as trees make in a high wind , though there was no wind to - night . Yet it was not exactly an ordinary tree - noise either . [Lucy]72-lucy felt there was a tune in it , but [she]72-lucy could not catch the tune any more than [she]72-lucy had been able to catch the words when the trees had so nearly talked to [her]72-lucy the night before . But there was , at least , a lilt ; [she]72-lucy felt [her]72-lucy own feet wanting to dance as [she]72-lucy got nearer . And now there was no doubt that the trees were really moving â€” moving in and out through one another as if in a complicated country dance . ( " And [I]72-lucy suppose , "[72-lucy] thought [Lucy]72-lucy , " when trees dance , it must be a very , very country dance indeed . "[72-lucy] ) [She]72-lucy was almost among [them]992-they now .

The first tree [she]72-lucy looked at seemed at first glance to be not a tree at all but [a huge man with a shaggy beard and great bushes of hair]994-a huge man with a shaggy beard and great bushes of hair . [She]72-lucy was not frightened : [she]72-lucy had seen such things before . But when [she]72-lucy looked again [he]994-a huge man with a shaggy beard and great bushes of hair was only a tree , though [he]994-a huge man with a shaggy beard and great bushes of hair was still moving . [You]995-you could n't see whether [he]994-a huge man with a shaggy beard and great bushes of hair had feet or roots , of course , because when trees move [they]992-they do n't walk on the surface of [the earth]996-the earth ; [they]992-they wade in it as [we]997-we do in water . The same thing happened with every tree [she]72-lucy looked at . At one moment [they]992-they seemed to be the friendly , lovely giant and giantess forms which [the tree - people]998-the tree - people put on when some good magic has called [them]992-they into full life : next moment [they]992-they all looked like trees again . But when [they]992-they looked like trees , it was like strangely human trees , and when [they]992-they looked like [people]2034-people , it was like [strangely branchy and leafy people]1000-strangely branchy and leafy people â€” and all the time that queer lilting , rustling , cool , merry noise .

" [They]992-they are almost awake , not quite , "[72-lucy] said [Lucy]72-lucy . [She]72-lucy knew [she]72-lucy [herself]72-lucy was wide awake , wider than [anyone]217-anyone usually is .

[She]72-lucy went fearlessly in among [them]992-they , dancing [herself]72-lucy at , [she]72-lucy leaped this way and that to avoid being run into by [these huge partners]1002-these huge partners . But [she]72-lucy was only half interested in [them]992-they . [She]72-lucy soon got through [them]992-they ( half wondering whether [she]72-lucy had been using [her]72-lucy arms to push branches aside , or to take hands in a Great Chain with [big dancers who stooped to reach [her]72-lucy]1004-big dancers who stooped to reach her ) for [they]992-they were really a ring of trees round [a central open place]1005-a central open place .
